citation.article-title: Mycoplasma melaleucae sp. nov., a sterol-requiring mollicute from flowers of several tropical plants.

p.s: Description of Mycoplasma melaleucae sp. nov.

Mycoplasma melaleucae (mel.a'leu.cae. N. L. n. Melaleuca, a genus of tropical trees having white flowers with sweet fragrance; N. L. fem. n. melaleucae, of Melaleuca, the plant from which strain M1T was first isolated)
Cells are nonhelical, pleomorphic, and coccoidal or subcoccoidal, with few filamentous forms, and lack a true cell wall.
Coccoidal forms average 250 to 300 nm in diameter.
Colonies on agar medium under optimum atmospheric conditions display a fried egg appearance.
Acid is produced from glucose and fructose.
Negative for sucrose, lactose, trehalose, and mannose.
Does not hydrolyze arginine or urea.
Does not hemadsorb guinea pig erythrocytes.
Cholesterol or serum is required for growth.
The temperature range for growth is 10 to 32°C; optimum growth occurs at 23 to 30°C.
Serologically distinct from other Mycoplasma species.
